docs.lead_paragraph: The smell lingers — the slightly sweet, slightly bitter odor of a chemical that contaminated the water supply of West Virginia's capital more than a week ago. It creeps out of faucets and shower heads. It wafts from the Elk River, the site of the spill. Sometimes it hangs in the cold nighttime air.

headline.main: Many Remain Wary of W.Va. Water as Smell Lingers
headline.print_headline: Many Remain Wary of W.Va. Water as Smell Lingers

docs.lead_paragraph: Johnson & Johnson’s Baby Shampoo no longer contains two potentially harmful chemicals, formaldehyde and 1,4-dioxane, that have come under increasing scrutiny by consumers.

headline.main: The ‘No More Tears’ Shampoo, Now With No Formaldehyde
headline.print_headline: The ‘No More Tears’ Shampoo, Now With No Formaldehyde

docs.abstract: Johnson & Johnson announces its trademark baby shampoo and 100 other baby products will no longer contain formaldehyde and 1,4-dioxane; move fulfills pledge made in the face of consumer pressure two years earlier and is first step in companywide effort to remove increasingly unpopular chemicals from its personal care products.
docs.snippet: Johnson & Johnson’s Baby Shampoo no longer contains two potentially harmful chemicals, formaldehyde and 1,4-dioxane, that have come under increasing scrutiny by consumers.

docs.lead_paragraph: Stuffy oil paintings of Cabinet secretaries are out. Old-style light bulbs win a reprieve. For the health care overhaul, it's a wash.
